Altered pages. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. | [[:en:WP:UCB|Use this bot]]. [[:en:WP:DBUG|Report bugs]]. | Suggested by Spinixster | [[Category:Classes of computers]] | #UCB_Category 70/91
rvv
/* Further reading */
/* Early computers */  RCA 601, H800 detailed cite
/* Later computers */ Mention the IBM midrange systems as being binary machines with decimal arithmetic instructions.

/* More modern computers */ Even the mainframes added vector instructions to do decimal integer arithmetic.  (Earlier models may have had them, or instructions like them, in millicode mode; the traditional decimal integer arithmetic instructions may have trapped to millicode.)
/* Later computers */ A bit more tense fixes.
/* Later computers */ Fix redlink.
/* Later computers */ Remove stray "d".
/* More modern computers */ Separate paragraphs for Power ISA and z/Architecture.

/* More modern computers */ Note that Power ISA 3.0 added some decimal *integer* instructions, most in the Vector Facility, but a couple in the Fixed-Point Facility.  (A USENET post a long time ago suggests that one of the latter, or a similar "provide a pile of 6'es" instruction, may have been added when AS/400 went with PowerPC.)
Dating maintenance tags: {{Cn}}

/* More modern computers */ What they added in Power ISA 2.05, starting with POWER6, was IEEE 754 decimal floating-point.  What S/360 and successors supported was decimal integer arithmetic (IEEE 754 decimal floating came later).  [[citation needed]] on "efforts to merge the iSeries and zSeries" (which didn't happen).  Distinguish between Power ISA (the [[IBM POWER architecture]] was an older ISA from which [[PowerPC]] and Power ISA were derived) and POWER6.
/* More modern computers */ Mention IEEE 754 decimal floating-point before we mention processors that support it.

/* Later computers */ Mention the binary [[Honeywell 6000 series]] as having added packed decimal arithmetic in the EIS machines, and mention the [[VAX]] as another line of binary computers with packed decimal arithmetic instructions.
/* Early computers */ Reference for 7090 CAQ instruction.  Also mention CVR, as the same manual gives a BCD addition routine using it.
/* Early computers */ Reference for the H800 having decimal arithmetic instructions.

Put the bit about early binary computers with some decimal capabilities in the "Early computers" section, so that the notion of "mainly binary, but with some help for decimal" is shown as having predated S/360.
/* Later computers */ Put the [[Burroughs Medium Systems]] in a section of its own; it was also a series, with the B2500 - and B3500 - being just the first two models.
/* Later computers */ Note that S/360 was a family of computers, not a particular computer.  The character encoding isn't relevantant here.
/* Later computers */ Emphasize S/360's binary nature.

Mention S/360, which was a binary machine with some decimal arithmetic instructions; that's where the future of decimal computing was going - decimal computers, in the sense of "everything's decimal, including addresses", were largely dead (the Burroughs Medium Systems remained for a while).
The title of the article is "decimal computer", not "decimal computers"; rewrite the first sentence to speak of what a decimal computer is, and copyedit it.
The 8080 ISA is not the 8086 ISA.
